item.title: Wall Street’s AI panic is real. The predictions probably won’t be.

item.description: If Iran’s regime must go, Trump will own what follows. And it’s not likely to be pretty.

item.description: The decline of mainline churches has left us more polarized.

item.description: How Vladimir Putin’s campaign of sabotage and intimidation boomeranged on Russia.

item.description: The U.S. men’s Olympic hockey team offered a triumph for all Americans. But some couldn’t enjoy it.

item.description: Failure is a foregone conclusion, but taxpayers will lose $70 million to find out for sure.

item.title: How can conservation backfire? Look at gray wolves.
item.description: Conservation works best when the U.S. government treats private landowners as partners.

item.description: Burden sharing can take many shapes, and benefit both domestic industry and allied economies.

item.title: RFK Jr.’s war on vaccines is coming for the elderly
item.description: The miseries of aging are more linked to late-life infections than was previously understood.

item.title: What it’s like to watch a dictatorship strangle your home country
item.description: This is not a time for optimism about Cuba — not yet. But I hope soon.

item.title: So much winning. But are we?
item.description: An upcoming Washington Post Opinions show. Stay tuned.

item.title: Banning stock trading for lawmakers is popular but unworkable
item.description: Requiring advance warning before buying and selling securities would be an easy and effective fix.

item.title: AI is coming. Is there enough power to run it?
item.description: We hear a lot about what artificial intelligence can do. We hear a lot less about what it takes to run it. The explosion of AI depends on massive data centers — and massive amounts of energy. Rep. Jake Auchincloss (D-Mass.) joins host Megan McArdle to discuss how his views on AI have evolved, and to explore how his state — and the nation — can meet the energy and infrastructure demands of the AI boom.

item.title: Tariff refunds are the only way
item.description: The government can do this the easy way or the hard way, but the stolen money needs to be returned.
